Question 1 (20%) Consider a sequence \(\{v_n\}\) in \(\mathbb{R}^m\). Show that \(\lVert v_n \lVert\) converges to \(0\) if and only if \(v_n\) converges to \(0\). Related Definition or Theorem Definition 1 The length or norm of vector \(x\) in \(\mathbb{R}^n\) is defined by \[\begin{align} \lVert x\rVert & = \left\{ \sum_{i=1}^n x_i^2 \right\}^{\frac{1}{2}} \end{align}\] where \(x = (x_1,\ldots,x_n)\). (Marsden, Hoffman, and others 1993, 59 Definition 1.6.5) Definition 2 The distance between two vectors \(x\) and \(y\) is the real number \[\begin{align} d(x,y) & = \lVert x-y \rVert \\ & = \left\{ \sum_{i=1}^{n} (x_i - y_i)^2 \right\}^{\frac{1}{2}} \end{align}\] where \(x = (x_1,\ldots,x_n)\) and \(y = (y_1,\ldots,y_n)\). (Marsden, Hoffman, and others 1993, 59 Definition 1.6.5) Solution (only if) (5%) Suppose that \[\begin{align} \lVert v_n \rVert \rightarrow 0 \end{align}\] as \(n\rightarrow \infty\). Given \(\varepsilon > 0\), there is \(N\in \mathbb{N}\) such that \[\begin{align} d\left(\lVert v_n \rVert, 0\right) < \varepsilon \end{align}\] if \(n\geq N\). (5%) By Definition 1 and Definition 2, \[\begin{align} d\left(\lVert v_n \rVert, 0\right) & = \lvert \lVert v_n \rVert \rvert \\ & = \lvert d(v_n, 0) \rvert \\ & = d(v_n, 0) < \varepsilon. \end{align}\] Thus, \(v_n\) converges to \(0\). Solution (if) (5%) Suppose that \[\begin{align} v_n \rightarrow 0 \end{align}\] as \(n\rightarrow \infty\). Given \(\varepsilon > 0\), there is \(N\in \mathbb{N}\) such that \[\begin{align} d\left( v_n, 0\right) < \varepsilon \end{align}\] if \(n\geq N\). (5%) By Definition 1 and Definition 2, \[\begin{align} d(v_n, 0) & = \lvert d(v_n, 0) \rvert \\ & = \lvert \lVert v_n \rVert \rvert \\ & = d\left(\lVert v_n \rVert, 0\right) < \varepsilon. \end{align}\] Thus, \(\lVert v_n \lVert\) converges to \(0\). Question 2 Consider a sequence \(\{x_n\}\) in \(\mathbb{R}^m\) converges to \(x\). (8%) Show that every subsequence of \(\{x_n\}\) converges. (6%) Explain why a subsequence of \(\{x_n\}\) cannot converge to a point different from \(x\). Solution (a) (3%) Suppose that \[\begin{align} x_n \rightarrow x \end{align}\] as \(n\rightarrow \infty\). Given \(\varepsilon > 0\), there is \(N\in \mathbb{N}\) such that \[\begin{align} d(x_n, x) < \varepsilon \end{align}\] if \(n \geq N\). (1%) Let \(\{x_{k(n)}\}\) be any subsequence of \(\{x_n\}\). (2%) We can find \[\begin{align} x_{k(n)} = x_m \end{align}\] for some \(m\geq n\geq N\). (2%) We have \[\begin{align} d(x_{k(n)}, x) & = d(x_m, x) < \varepsilon. \end{align}\] Thus, every subsequence of \(\{x_n\}\) converges to \(x\). Solution (b) (2%) Suppose that \(\{x_{k(n)}\}\) converges to \(x\) and to \(y\). Given \(\varepsilon > 0\), there is \(N_x, N_y \in \mathbb{N}\) such that \[\begin{align} k(n)\geq N_x & \quad \Rightarrow \quad d(x_{k(n)}, x) < \frac{\varepsilon}{2} \\ k(n)\geq N_x & \quad \Rightarrow \quad d(x_{k(n)}, y) < \frac{\varepsilon}{2}. \end{align}\] (2%) Take \(k(n) \geq N = \max\{ N_x, N_y\}\). We have \[\begin{align} d(x,y) & \leq d(x_{k(n)}, x) + d(x_{k(n)}, y) \\ & < \frac{\varepsilon}{2} + \frac{\varepsilon}{2} = \varepsilon. \end{align}\] (2%) Because \(\varepsilon\) is arbitrary, \[\begin{align} d(x,y) = 0. \end{align}\] That is, \(x = y\).

Question 3 (6%) Let \(\{x_n\}\) and \(\{y_n\}\) be two bounded sequence in \(\mathbb{R}\). Show that given any \(n\), \[\begin{align} \inf \left\{ x_n+y_n, x_{n+1}+y_{n+1}, \ldots \right\} & \geq \inf \left\{ x_n, x_{n+1}, \ldots \right\} + \inf \left\{ y_n, y_{n+1}, \ldots \right\}. \end{align}\] Solution (2%) By definition of infimum, we know \[\begin{align} \inf\{ x_n, x_{n+1}, \ldots \} & \leq x_k, \quad \forall k\geq n \\ \inf\{ y_n, y_{n+1}, \ldots \} & \leq y_k, \quad \forall k\geq n. \end{align}\] (2%) Then, \[\begin{align} \inf\{ x_n, x_{n+1}, \ldots \} + \inf\{ y_n, y_{n+1}, \ldots \} \end{align}\] is a lower bound for the set \(\left\{ x_n+y_n, x_{n+1}+y_{n+1}, \ldots \right\}\). (2%) Because infimum is the greatest lower bound, \[\begin{align} \inf \left\{ x_n+y_n, x_{n+1}+y_{n+1}, \ldots \right\} & \geq \inf \left\{ x_n, x_{n+1}, \ldots \right\} + \inf \left\{ y_n, y_{n+1}, \ldots \right\}. \end{align}\]

Question 5 The functions \(F\) and \(G\) are defined as \[\begin{align} F(x) & = 2x + 1, \quad x > 0 \end{align}\] and \[\begin{align} G(x) & = \begin{cases} \frac{1}{x}, & \mbox{if } x\geq 1 \\ 0, & \mbox{if } x < 1. \end{cases} \end{align}\] (6%) Verify that \(\mathcal{R}(F) \subseteq \mathcal{D}(G)\). Find the domain and range of \((G \circ F)(x)\). (2%) Find the formula for \((G \circ F)(x)\). Solution (a) We know (1%) \(\mathcal{R}(F) = (1,\infty)\); (1%) \(\mathcal{D}(G) = \mathbb{R}\). It is obvious that \[\begin{align} \mathcal{R}(F) \subseteq \mathcal{D}(G). \end{align}\] Moreover, we find (2%) \(\mathcal{D}(G\circ F) = (0, \infty)\); (2%) \(\mathcal{R}(G\circ F) = (0,1)\). Solution (b) (2%) We find \[\begin{align} (G\circ F)(x) & = \frac{1}{2x+1}, \quad x > 0. \end{align}\]

Question 6 Consider a function \(f: S\rightarrow T\), with \(A \subset S\) and \(B \subset T\). (4%) Define the set of \(f^{-1}\left( f(A) \right)\). (4%) Define the set of \(f\left( f^{-1}(B) \right)\). Solution (a) (4%) \[\begin{align} f^{-1}\left( f(A) \right) & = \{ s\in S \mid \exists a\in A \mbox{ such that } f(a) = f(s) \} \end{align}\] Solution (b) (4%) \[\begin{align} f\left( f^{-1}(B) \right) & = \{ t\in T \mid \exists s\in f^{-1}(B) \mbox{ such that } f(s) = t \} \end{align}\]

Question 7 Suppose that a function is \[\begin{align} f & = \left\{ (1,3), (2,5), (3,8), (4,10), (5,11), (6,4), (7,6), (8,8), (9,10), (10,12) \right\}, \end{align}\] so this is a function from \(\{ 1,2,\ldots,10 \}\) into \(\mathbb{R}\). Let \(A = \{ 1,2,3 \}\) and \(B = \{ 6,8,10,12,15 \}\). (4%) Write down all the elements in \(f^{-1}\left( f(A) \right)\). (4%) Write down all the elements in \(f\left( f^{-1}(B) \right)\). Question 8 (8%) Suppose \(a\) and \(b\) are real numbers. Find \(a\) and \(b\) such that the following vectors in \(\mathbb{R}^4\) are linearly dependent. \[\begin{align} v_1 = \begin{bmatrix} 1 \\ 2 \\ -2 \\ 4 \end{bmatrix}, \quad v_2 = \begin{bmatrix} 0 \\ 1 \\ 1 \\ 2 \end{bmatrix}, \quad v_3 = \begin{bmatrix} 2 \\ -1 \\ a \\ b \end{bmatrix} \end{align}\] Solution (4%) By Gauss-Jordan elimination, \[\begin{align} \begin{bmatrix} 1 & 2 & -2 & 4 \\ 0 & 1 & 1 & 2 \\ 2 & -1 & a & b \end{bmatrix} & \longrightarrow \begin{bmatrix} 1 & 2 & -2 & 4 \\ 0 & 1 & 1 & 2 \\ 0 & -5 & a+4 & b-8 \end{bmatrix} \\ & \longrightarrow \begin{bmatrix} 1 & 2 & -2 & 4 \\ 0 & 1 & 1 & 2 \\ 0 & 0 & a+9 & b+2 \end{bmatrix}. \end{align}\] Thus, (2%) \(a = -9\); (2%) \(b = -2\).

Question 9 \[\begin{align} A & = \begin{bmatrix} 1 & 2 \\ 3 & 2 \end{bmatrix} \end{align}\] (5%) Find the eigenvalues and eigenvectors of \(A\). (3%) There exists a unique solution to solve \(Ax = b\) for every \(b\). True or False? Solution (a) (1%) We find \[\begin{align} \det (A - \lambda I) & = \begin{vmatrix} 1-\lambda & 2 \\ 3 & 2-\lambda \end{vmatrix} \\ & = (1-\lambda)(2-\lambda) - 6 \\ & = (\lambda - 4)(\lambda + 1) = 0. \end{align}\] Then, \[\begin{align} \lambda_1 & = 4 \\ \lambda_2 & = -1. \end{align}\] (1%) For \(\lambda_1 = 4\), \[\begin{align} [A - 4I \mid 0] & = \begin{bmatrix} -3 & 2 & \mid & 0 \\ 3 & -2 & \mid & 0 \\ \end{bmatrix} \\ & \rightarrow \begin{bmatrix} -3 & 2 & \mid & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & \mid & 0 \end{bmatrix}. \end{align}\] (1%) We find an eigenvector \[\begin{align} \begin{bmatrix} x_1 \\ x_2 \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} 2 \\ 3 \end{bmatrix} \end{align}\] corresponding to \(\lambda_1 = 4\). (1%) For \(\lambda_2 = -1\), \[\begin{align} [A - (-1)I \mid 0] & = \begin{bmatrix} 2 & 2 & \mid & 0 \\ 3 & 3 & \mid & 0 \\ \end{bmatrix} \\ & \rightarrow \begin{bmatrix} 2 & 2 & \mid & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & \mid & 0 \end{bmatrix}. \end{align}\] (1%) We find an eigenvector \[\begin{align} \begin{bmatrix} x_1 \\ x_2 \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} 1 \\ -1 \end{bmatrix} \end{align}\] corresponding to \(\lambda_2 = -1\). Solution (b) (1%) True. (2%) We find \[\begin{align} \mbox{rank} (A) = 2 \end{align}\] and \[\begin{align} \det (A) \neq 0. \end{align}\]

Question 10 Discuss why the following proofs are incorrect. (5%) Prove that is a sequence has only one limit point \(p\), then this sequence converges. Proof. Letâ€™s prove by contradiction. Suppose that the sequence \(x_n\) does not converge to \(p\). Then there exists an \(\varepsilon > 0\) and for all \(N\) such that \(d(x_n, p) \geq \varepsilon\) if \(n\geq N\). Then we find an \(\varepsilon\) that there are finite indices \(n\) for which \(d(x_n, p) < \varepsilon\). Therefore, \(p\) cannot be a limit point. (5%) Suppose that \(x_n\rightarrow 0\). Show that \[\begin{align} \lim_{n\rightarrow \infty} x_n \sin\frac{1}{x_n} = 0. \end{align}\] Proof. By \[\begin{align} \lim_{n\rightarrow \infty} a_nb_n & = \lim_{n\rightarrow \infty} a_n \lim_{n\rightarrow \infty} b_n, \end{align}\] we have \[\begin{align} \lim_{n\rightarrow \infty} x_n \sin\frac{1}{x_n} & = \lim_{n\rightarrow \infty} x_n \lim_{n\rightarrow \infty} \sin\frac{1}{x_n}. \end{align}\] Because the range of \(\sin \frac{1}{x_n}\) is bounded in \([-1,1]\), and \(x_n\) tends to zero as \(n\) sufficiently large, the product of the two must eventually tend to zero. Related Definition or Theorem Theorem 1 Suppose \(\{s_n\}, \{t_n\}\) are complex sequences, and \[\begin{align} \lim_{n\rightarrow \infty} s_n & = s \\ \lim_{n\rightarrow \infty} t_n & = t. \end{align}\] Then, \[\begin{align} \lim_{n\rightarrow \infty} s_n t_n = st. \end{align}\] (Rudin and others 1964, 3:49 Theorem 3.3 (c)) Solution (a) (5%) The statement Then there exists an \(\varepsilon > 0\) and for all \(N\) such that \(d(x_n, p) \geq \varepsilon\) if \(n\geq N\). is wrong. The correct statement is Then there exists an \(\varepsilon > 0\) and for all \(N\) such that there exists \(n\geq N\), \[\begin{align} d(x_n, p) \geq \varepsilon. \end{align}\] Solution (b) (5%) Because we are not sure whether \[\begin{align} \lim_{n\rightarrow \infty} \sin\frac{1}{x_n} \end{align}\] exists, we cannot use Theorem 1. Question 1 Let \(S=\left\{ x\in \mathbb{R} \mid x= 1- \frac{1}{n}, \ n \in \mathbb{Z}^{+} \right\} \cup \left\{1 \right\}.\) (6%) Is \(S\) closed? (6%) Is it compact? (6%) Is it convex? Related Definition or Theorem Definition 3 A set \(E \in \mathbb{R}^{k}\) is convex if \[\begin{align} \lambda x + (1 - \lambda) y \in E \end{align}\] where \(x\in E, y\in E,\) and \(\lambda \in [0,1]\). (Rudin and others 1964, 3:31) Definition 4 Let \(X\) be a metric space. \(E\) is bounded if there is a real number \(M\) and a point \(q\in X\) such that \(d\left( p,q \right) < M\) for all \(p\in E\). (Rudin and others 1964, 3:34 Definition 2.18 (i)) Theorem 2 A set \(S\) is open if and only if its complement \(S^C\) is closed. (Rudin and others 1964, 3:34 Theorem 2.23) Theorem 3 For any collection \(\left\{ G_\alpha \right\}\) of open sets, \(\bigcup_\alpha G_\alpha\) is open. (Rudin and others 1964, 3:34 Theorem 2.24 (i)) Theorem 4 (Heine-Borel Theorem) A set \(A \subset \mathbb{R}^n\) is compact if and only if it is closed and bounded. (Marsden, Hoffman, and others 1993, 155 Theorem 3.2.1) Solution (a) We know \[\begin{align} S & = \left\{ x\in \mathbb{R} \mid x = 1 - \frac{1}{n}, n\in \mathbb{Z}^+ \right\} \cup \left\{1 \right\} \\ & = \left\{ 0, \frac{1}{2}, \frac{2}{3}, \frac{3}{4}, \ldots, 1 \right\}. \end{align}\] (2%) Then, \[\begin{align} S^{C} & = \left( -\infty, 0 \right) \cup T \cup (1,\infty). \end{align}\] where \[\begin{align} T & = \bigcup_{n\in \mathbb{N}} \left( 1-\frac{1}{n}, 1-\frac{1}{n+1} \right). \end{align}\] (2%) By Theorem 3, \(S^C\) is open. (2%) By Theorem 2, \(S\) is closed. Solution (b) (2%) Take \(r = 2\). (2%) Then, \[\begin{align} S \subset B(0, r). \end{align}\] That is, \(S\) is bounded by Definition 4. (2%) By Theorem 4, \(S\) is compact. Solution (c) (3%) Let \[\begin{align} x_1 & = 0 \in S \\ x_2 & = \frac{1}{2} \in S \\ \theta & = \frac{1}{2} \in [0,1]. \end{align}\] (3%) Then, \[\begin{align} \theta x_1 + \left( 1-\theta \right) x_2 & = \frac{1}{2}\cdot 0 + \left( 1-\frac{1}{2} \right) \cdot \frac{1}{2} \\ & = \frac{1}{4} \notin S. \end{align}\] Thus, \(S\) is not convex by Definition 3. Question 2 (8%) Consider \(f: \mathbb{R}^n \rightarrow \mathbb{R}\). Define \[\begin{align} U_f\left( \overline{v} \right) & =\{ x \mid f(x) \geq \overline{v} \} \end{align}\] where \(\overline{v} \in \mathbb{R}\). Show that \(U_f\left( \overline{v} \right)\) is a convex set for every \(\overline{v}\) if \[\begin{align} f\left( \theta x^a +(1-\theta) x^b \right) & \geq \theta f\left( x^a \right) + \left( 1-\theta \right) f\left( x^b \right) \end{align}\] for all \(x^a\) and \(x^b\) and for all \(\theta \in [0, 1]\). Solution (2%) Take \[\begin{align} x^a & \in U_f\left( \overline{v} \right) \quad \Rightarrow \quad f(x^a) \geq \overline{v} \\ x^b & \in U_f\left( \overline{v} \right) \quad \Rightarrow \quad f(x^b) \geq \overline{v}. \end{align}\] (2%) We get \[\begin{align} \theta f(x^a) + (1-\theta) f(x^b) & \geq \theta \overline{v} + (1-\theta) \overline{v} \\ & = \overline{v} \end{align}\] where \(\theta \in [0,1]\). (2%) Then, \[\begin{align} f\left( \theta x^a +(1-\theta) x^b \right) & \geq \theta f\left( x^a \right) + \left( 1-\theta \right) f\left( x^b \right) \\ & \geq \overline{v}. \end{align}\] (2%) Thus, \[\begin{align} \theta x^a + (1-\theta) x^b \in U_f\left( \overline{v} \right). \end{align}\] That is, \(U_f \left( \overline{v} \right)\) is a convex set for every \(\overline{v}\).

Question 4 (6%) Consider \(f: [a, b] \rightarrow \mathbb{R}\), and its derivatives exist at every point in \((a, b)\) and \(f\) continuous at both end points. Assume that \(f'(x) > 0\) for all \(x \in (a, b)\). Prove that \(f(b) > f(a)\). Question 5 Consider a function \(f: \mathbb{R}^3 \rightarrow \mathbb{R}\) as follows. \[\begin{align} f(x_1, x_2, x_3) & = \begin{cases} \frac{x_1 x_2 + x_3 ^2 }{x_1^2 + x_2^2 + 2x_3^2}, & \quad \mbox{if } (x_1, x_2, x_3) \neq (1,1,1) \\ 0, & \quad \mbox{if } (x_1, x_2, x_3) = (1,1,1). \end{cases} \end{align}\] (6%) Show that \(f\) is not continuous at \((1,1,1)\). (6%) Show that \(\frac{\partial f(x_1, x_2, x_3)}{\partial x_3}\) does not exist at \((1, 1, 1)\). Solution (a) (2%) Consider a sequence \(\{x_n\}\) with \[\begin{align} x_{in} = 1 + \frac{1}{n} \end{align}\] where \(x_n = (x_{1n}, x_{2n}, x_{3n})\) and \(i=1,2,3\). (2%) We know \[\begin{align} x_n \rightarrow (1,1,1) \end{align}\] as \(n \rightarrow \infty\). (2%) We find \[\begin{align} \lim_{n\rightarrow \infty} f(x_n) & = \lim_{n\rightarrow \infty} \frac{2\left( 1+\frac{1}{n} \right)^2}{4\left( 1+\frac{1}{n} \right)^2} = \frac{1}{2} \\ & \neq f(1,1,1) = 0. \end{align}\] Thus, \(f\) is not continuous at \((1,1,1)\). Solution (b) (6%) We find \[\begin{align} \frac{\partial f}{\partial x_3}(1,1,1) & = \lim_{h\rightarrow 0} \frac{f(1,1,1+h) - f(1,1,1)}{h} \\ & = \lim_{h\rightarrow 0} \frac{\frac{1+(1+h)^2}{1+1+2(1+h)^2} - 0}{h} \\ & = \lim_{h\rightarrow 0} \frac{1}{2h} = \infty. \end{align}\] Thus, \(\frac{\partial f(x_1, x_2, x_3)}{\partial x_3}\) does not exist at \((1, 1, 1)\).

Question 6 Discuss why the following proofs are incorrect. (5%) Consider \(f: S \subset \mathbb{R} \rightarrow \mathbb{R}\), where \(S\) is an open set in \(\mathbb{R}\). Assume that \(f\) is continuous at a point \(c\) in \(S\) and that \(f(c) > 0\). Prove that there exists an open set \(U \subset S\), such that for all \(x \in U\), \(f(x) > 0\). Proof. Because \(f(c)\) is an interior point of \((0, \infty)\), there exists a \(\delta > 0\) such that \[\begin{align} B\left(f(c), \delta \right) \subset (0, \infty). \end{align}\] Because \(B\left(f(c), \delta \right)\) is an open set in \(\mathbb{R}\), its inverse image \(f^{-1}\left( B\left(f(c), \delta\right) \right)\) is open in \(S\). Therefore, we find an open set \(U = f^{-1}\left( B\left(f(c), \delta \right) \right)\) in \(S\) such that for all \(x \in f^{-1}\left( B\left(f(c), \delta \right) \right)\), \[\begin{align} f(x) \in B\left(f(c), \delta \right) \subset (0, \infty), \end{align}\] implying that \(f(x)>0\). (5%) Prove that if \(S_1\) and \(S_2\) are compact, then \(S_1+S_2\) is compact. Proof. Pick any sequence \(\{ z_n \}\) and \(z_n \in S_1 + S_2\) for all \(n\). We want to show that we can find a convergent subsequence of \(\{ z_n \}\) such that its limit \(z\) is in \(S_1 + S_2\). Because \(z_n \in S_1+S_2\), this implies that we can find a point \(x_n \in S_1\) and \(y_n \in S_2\) such that \(z_n = x_n + y_n\).
